Le Morte D’Arthur

King Arthur and of his Noble Knights of the Round Table

by Thomas Malory

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000005": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000005", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

IN TWO VOLS.—VOL. I

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000006": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000006", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000007": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000007", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Contents

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000008": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000008", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000010">BIBLIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000023">PREFACE OF WILLIAM CAXTON
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000034">BOOK I.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000037">CHAPTER I. First, How Uther Pendragon sent for the duke of Cornwall and Igraine his wife, and of their departing suddenly again.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000050">CHAPTER II. How Uther Pendragon made war on the duke of Cornwall, and how by the mean of Merlin he lay by the duchess and gat Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000059">CHAPTER III. Of the birth of King Arthur and of his nurture.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000066">CHAPTER IV. Of the death of King Uther Pendragon.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000071">CHAPTER V. How Arthur was chosen king, and of wonders and marvels of a sword taken out of a stone by the said Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000080">CHAPTER VI. How King Arthur pulled out the sword divers times.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000089">CHAPTER VII. How King Arthur was crowned, and how he made officers.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000096">CHAPTER VIII. How King Arthur held in Wales, at a Pentecost, a great feast, and what kings and lords came to his feast.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000101">CHAPTER IX. Of the first war that King Arthur had, and how he won the field.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000108">CHAPTER X. How Merlin counselled King Arthur to send for King Ban and King Bors, and of their counsel taken for the war.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000117">CHAPTER XI. Of a great tourney made by King Arthur and the two kings Ban and Bors, and how they went over the sea.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000126">CHAPTER XII. How eleven kings gathered a great host against King Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000133">CHAPTER XIII. Of a dream of the King with the Hundred Knights.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000140">CHAPTER XIV. How the eleven kings with their host fought against Arthur and his host, and many great feats of the war.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000149">CHAPTER XV. Yet of the same battle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000158">CHAPTER XVI. Yet more of the same battle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000169">CHAPTER XVII. Yet more of the same battle, and how it was ended by Merlin.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000176">CHAPTER XVIII. How King Arthur, King Ban, and King Bors rescued King Leodegrance, and other incidents.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000183">CHAPTER XIX. How King Arthur rode to Carlion, and of his dream, and how he saw the questing beast.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000190">CHAPTER XX. How King Pellinore took Arthur's horse and followed the Questing Beast, and how Merlin met with Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000197">CHAPTER XXI. How Ulfius impeached Queen Igraine, Arthur's mother, of treason; and how a knight came and desired to have the death of his master revenged.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000206">CHAPTER XXII. How Griflet was made knight, and jousted with a knight
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000211">CHAPTER XXIII. How twelve knights came from Rome and asked truage for this land of Arthur, and how Arthur fought with a knight.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000218">CHAPTER XXIV. How Merlin saved Arthur's life, and threw an enchantment on King Pellinore and made him to sleep.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000223">CHAPTER XXV. How Arthur by the mean of Merlin gat Excalibur his sword of the Lady of the Lake.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000230">CHAPTER XXVI. How tidings came to Arthur that King Rience had overcome eleven kings, and how he desired Arthur's beard to trim his mantle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000237">CHAPTER XXVII. How all the children were sent for that were born on May-day, and how Mordred was saved.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000244">BOOK II.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000247">CHAPTER I. Of a damosel which came girt with a sword for to find a man of such virtue to draw it out of the scabbard.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000256">CHAPTER II. How Balin, arrayed like a poor knight, pulled out the sword, which afterward was the cause of his death.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000263">CHAPTER III. How the Lady of the Lake demanded the knight's head that had won the sword, or the maiden's head.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000270">CHAPTER IV. How Merlin told the adventure of this damosel.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000275">CHAPTER V. How Balin was pursued by Sir Lanceor, knight of Ireland, and how he jousted and slew him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000282">CHAPTER VI. How a damosel, which was love to Lanceor, slew herself for love, and how Balin met with his brother Balan.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000287">CHAPTER VII. How a dwarf reproved Balin for the death of Lanceor, and how King Mark of Cornwall found them, and made a tomb over them.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000292">CHAPTER VIII. How Merlin prophesied that two the best knights of the world should fight there, which were Sir Lancelot and Sir Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000297">CHAPTER IX. How Balin and his brother, by the counsel of Merlin, took King Rience and brought him to King Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000304">CHAPTER X. How King Arthur had a battle against Nero and King Lot of Orkney, and how King Lot was deceived by Merlin, and how twelve kings were slain.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000311">CHAPTER XI. Of the interment of twelve kings, and of the prophecy of Merlin, and how Balin should give the dolorous stroke.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000316">CHAPTER XII. How a sorrowful knight came before Arthur, and how Balin fetched him, and how that knight was slain by a knight invisible.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000321">CHAPTER XIII. How Balin and the damosel met with a knight which was in likewise slain, and how the damosel bled for the custom of a castle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000326">CHAPTER XIV. How Balin met with that knight named Garlon at a feast, and there he slew him, to have his blood to heal therewith the son of his host.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000333">CHAPTER XV. How Balin fought with King Pellam, and how his sword brake, and how he gat a spear wherewith he smote the dolorous stroke.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000338">CHAPTER XVI. How Balin was delivered by Merlin, and saved a knight that would have slain himself for love.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000345">CHAPTER XVII. How that knight slew his love and a knight lying by her, and after, how he slew himself with his own sword, and how Balin rode toward a castle where he lost his life.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000352">CHAPTER XVIII. How Balin met with his brother Balan, and how each of them slew other unknown, till they were wounded to death.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000361">CHAPTER XIX. How Merlin buried them both in one tomb, and of Balin's sword.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000370">BOOK III.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000373">CHAPTER I. How King Arthur took a wife, and wedded Guenever, daughter to Leodegrance, King of the Land of Cameliard, with whom he had the Round Table.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000380">CHAPTER II. How the Knights of the Round Table were ordained and their sieges blessed by the Bishop of Canterbury.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000385">CHAPTER III. How a poor man riding upon a lean mare desired King Arthur to make his son knight.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000392">CHAPTER IV. How Sir Tor was known for son of King Pellinore, and how Gawaine was made knight.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000397">CHAPTER V. How at feast of the wedding of King Arthur to Guenever, a white hart came into the hall, and thirty couple hounds, and how a brachet pinched the hart which was taken away.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000404">CHAPTER VI. How Sir Gawaine rode for to fetch again the hart, and how two brethren fought each against other for the hart.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000411">CHAPTER VII How the hart was chased into a castle and there slain, and how Sir Gawaine slew a lady.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000418">CHAPTER VIII. How four knights fought against Gawaine and Gaheris, and how they were overcome, and their lives saved at request of four ladies.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000425">CHAPTER IX. How Sir Tor rode after the knight with the brachet, and of his adventure by the way.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000430">CHAPTER X. How Sir Tor found the brachet with a lady, and how a knight assailed him for the said brachet.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000437">CHAPTER XI. How Sir Tor overcame the knight, and how he lost his head at the request of a lady.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000444">CHAPTER XII. How King Pellinore rode after the lady and the knight that led her away, and how a lady desired help of him, and how he fought with two knights for that lady, of whom he slew the one at the first stroke.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000451">CHAPTER XIII. How King Pellinore gat the lady and brought her to Camelot to the court of King Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000458">CHAPTER XIV. How on the way he heard two knights, as he lay by night in a valley, and of their adventures.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000463">CHAPTER XV. How when he was come to Camelot he was sworn upon a book to tell the truth of his quest.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000472">BOOK IV.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000475">CHAPTER I. How Merlin was assotted and doted on one of the ladies of the lake, and how he was shut in a rock under a stone and there died.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000482">CHAPTER II. How five kings came into this land to war against King Arthur, and what counsel Arthur had against them.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000487">CHAPTER III. How King Arthur had ado with them and overthrew them, and slew the five kings and made the remnant to flee.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000496">CHAPTER IV. How the battle was finished or he came, and how King Arthur founded an abbey where the battle was.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000503">CHAPTER V. How Sir Tor was made knight of the Round Table, and how Bagdemagus was displeased.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000510">CHAPTER VI. How King Arthur, King Uriens, and Sir Accolon of Gaul, chased an hart, and of their marvellous adventures.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000517">CHAPTER VII. How Arthur took upon him to fight to be delivered out of prison, and also for to deliver twenty knights that were in prison.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000526">CHAPTER VIII. How Accolon found himself by a well, and he took upon him to do battle against Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000535">CHAPTER IX. Of the battle between King Arthur and Accolon.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000542">CHAPTER X. How King Arthur's sword that he fought with brake, and how he recovered of Accolon his own sword Excalibur, and overcame his enemy.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000549">CHAPTER XI. How Accolon confessed the treason of Morgan le Fay, King Arthur's sister, and how she would have done slay him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000556">CHAPTER XII. How Arthur accorded the two brethren, and delivered the twenty knights, and how Sir Accolon died.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000561">CHAPTER XIII. How Morgan would have slain Sir Uriens her husband, and how Sir Uwaine her son saved him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000566">CHAPTER XIV. How Queen Morgan le Fay made great sorrow for the death of Accolon, and how she stole away the scabbard from Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000575">CHAPTER XV. How Morgan le Fay saved a knight that should have been drowned, and how King Arthur returned home again.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000582">CHAPTER XVI. How the Damosel of the Lake saved King Arthur from mantle that should have burnt him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000587">CHAPTER XVII. How Sir Gawaine and Sir Uwaine met with twelve fair damosels, and how they complained on Sir Marhaus.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000592">CHAPTER XVIII. How Sir Marhaus jousted with Sir Gawaine and Sir Uwaine, and overthrew them both.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000601">CHAPTER XIX. How Sir Marhaus, Sir Gawaine, and Sir Uwaine met three damosels, and each of them took one.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000606">CHAPTER XX. How a knight and a dwarf strove for a lady.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000617">CHAPTER XXI. How King Pelleas suffered himself to be taken prisoner because he would have a sight of his lady, and how Sir Gawaine promised him to get to him the love of his lady.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000624">CHAPTER XXII. How Sir Gawaine came to the Lady Ettard, and how Sir Pelleas found them sleeping.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000637">CHAPTER XXIII. How Sir Pelleas loved no more Ettard by means of the Damosel of the Lake, whom he loved ever after.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000642">CHAPTER XXIV. How Sir Marhaus rode with the damosel, and how he came to the Duke of the South Marches.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000649">CHAPTER XXV. How Sir Marhaus fought with the duke and his four sons and made them to yield them.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000658">CHAPTER XXVI. How Sir Uwaine rode with the damosel of sixty year of age, and how he gat the prize at tourneying.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000665">CHAPTER XXVII. How Sir Uwaine fought with two knights and overcame them.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000670">CHAPTER XXVIII. How at the year's end all three knights with their three damosels met at the fountain.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000679">BOOK V.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000682">CHAPTER I. How twelve aged ambassadors of Rome came to King Arthur to demand truage for Britain.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000689">CHAPTER II. How the kings and lords promised to King Arthur aid and help against the Romans.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000700">CHAPTER III. How King Arthur held a parliament at York, and how he ordained the realm should be governed in his absence.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000705">CHAPTER IV. How King Arthur being shipped and lying in his cabin had a marvellous dream and of the exposition thereof.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000714">CHAPTER V. How a man of the country told to him of a marvellous giant, and how he fought and conquered him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000729">CHAPTER VI. How King Arthur sent Sir Gawaine and other to Lucius, and how they were assailed and escaped with worship.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000738">CHAPTER VII. How Lucius sent certain spies in a bushment for to have taken his knights being prisoners, and how they were letted.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000745">CHAPTER VIII. How a senator told to Lucius of their discomfiture, and also of the great battle between Arthur and Lucius.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000758">CHAPTER IX How Arthur, after he had achieved the battle against the Romans, entered into Almaine, and so into Italy.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000765">CHAPTER X. Of a battle done by Sir Gawaine against a Saracen, which after was yielden and became Christian.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000774">CHAPTER XI. How the Saracens came out of a wood for to rescue their beasts, and of a great battle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000785">CHAPTER XII. How Sir Gawaine returned to King Arthur with his prisoners, and how the King won a city, and how he was crowned Emperor.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000798">BOOK VI.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000801">CHAPTER I. How Sir Launcelot and Sir Lionel departed from the court, and how Sir Lionel left him sleeping and was taken.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000810">CHAPTER II. How Sir Ector followed for to seek Sir Launcelot, and how he was taken by Sir Turquine.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000817">CHAPTER III How four queens found Launcelot sleeping, and how by enchantment he was taken and led into a castle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000826">CHAPTER IV. How Sir Launcelot was delivered by the mean of a damosel.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000833">CHAPTER V. How a knight found Sir Launcelot lying in his leman's bed, and how Sir Launcelot fought with the knight.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000842">CHAPTER VI. How Sir Launcelot was received of King Bagdemagus' daughter, and how he made his complaint to her father.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000851">CHAPTER VII. How Sir Launcelot behaved him in a tournament, and how he met with Sir Turquine leading Sir Gaheris.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000862">CHAPTER VIII. How Sir Launcelot and Sir Turquine fought together.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000871">CHAPTER IX. How Sir Turquine was slain, and how Sir Launcelot bade Sir Gaheris deliver all the prisoners.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000880">CHAPTER X. How Sir Launcelot rode with a damosel and slew a knight that distressed all ladies and also a villain that kept a bridge.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000891">CHAPTER XI. How Sir Launcelot slew two giants, and made a castle free.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000902">CHAPTER XII. How Sir Launcelot rode disguised in Sir Kay's harness, and how he smote down a knight.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000911">CHAPTER XIII. How Sir Launcelot jousted against four knights of the Round Table and overthrew them.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000920">CHAPTER XIV. How Sir Launcelot followed a brachet into a castle, where he found a dead knight, and how he after was required of a damosel to heal her brother.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000925">CHAPTER XV. How Sir Launcelot came into the Chapel Perilous and gat there of a dead corpse a piece of the cloth and a sword.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000934">CHAPTER XVI. How Sir Launcelot at the request of a lady recovered a falcon, by which he was deceived.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000943">CHAPTER XVII. How Sir Launcelot overtook a knight which chased his wife to have slain her, and how he said to him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000952">CHAPTER XVIII. How Sir Launcelot came to King Arthur's Court, and how there were recounted all his noble feats and acts.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000963">BOOK VII.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000966">CHAPTER I. How Beaumains came to King Arthur's Court and demanded three petitions of King Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000977">CHAPTER II. How Sir Launcelot and Sir Gawaine were wroth because Sir Kay mocked Beaumains, and of a damosel which desired a knight to fight for a lady.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000990">CHAPTER III. How Beaumains desired the battle, and how it was granted to him, and how he desired to be made knight of Sir Launcelot.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000995">CHAPTER IV. How Beaumains departed, and how he gat of Sir Kay a spear and a shield, and how he jousted with Sir Launcelot.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001002">CHAPTER V. How Beaumains told to Sir Launcelot his name, and how he was dubbed knight of Sir Launcelot, and after overtook the damosel.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001015">CHAPTER VI. How Beaumains fought and slew two knights at a passage.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001024">CHAPTER VII. How Beaumains fought with the Knight of the Black Launds, and fought with him till he fell down and died.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001035">CHAPTER VIII. How the brother of the knight that was slain met with Beaumains, and fought with Beaumains till he was yielden.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001044">CHAPTER IX. How the damosel again rebuked Beaumains, and would not suffer him to sit at her table, but called him kitchen boy.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001051">CHAPTER X. How the third brother, called the Red Knight, jousted and fought against Beaumains, and how Beaumains overcame him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001060">CHAPTER XI. How Sir Beaumains suffered great rebukes of the damosel, and he suffered it patiently.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001071">CHAPTER XII. How Beaumains fought with Sir Persant of Inde, and made him to be yielden.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001078">CHAPTER XIII. Of the goodly communication between Sir Persant and Beaumains, and how he told him that his name was Sir Gareth.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001087">CHAPTER XIV. How the lady that was besieged had word from her sister how she had brought a knight to fight for her, and what battles he had achieved.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001098">CHAPTER XV. How the damosel and Beaumains came to the siege; and came to a sycamore tree, and there Beaumains blew a horn, and then the Knight of the Red Launds came to fight with him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001111">CHAPTER XVI. How the two knights met together, and of their talking, and how they began their battle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001120">CHAPTER XVII. How after long fighting Beaumains overcame the knight and would have slain him, but at the request of the lords he saved his life, and made him to yield him to the lady.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001133">CHAPTER XVIII. How the knight yielded him, and how Beaumains made him to go unto King Arthur's court, and to cry Sir Launcelot mercy.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001140">CHAPTER XIX How Beaumains came to the lady, and when he came to the castle the gates were closed against him, and of the words that the lady said to him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001153">CHAPTER XX. How Sir Beaumains rode after to rescue his dwarf, and came into the castle where he was.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001164">CHAPTER XXI. How Sir Gareth, otherwise called Beaumains, came to the presence of his lady, and how they took acquaintance, and of their love.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001173">CHAPTER XXII. How at night came an armed knight, and fought with Sir Gareth, and he, sore hurt in the thigh, smote off the knight's head.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001186">CHAPTER XXIII. How the said knight came again the next night and was beheaded again, and how at the feast of Pentecost all the knights that Sir Gareth had overcome came and yielded them to King Arthur.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001197">CHAPTER XXIV. How King Arthur pardoned them, and demanded of them where Sir Gareth was.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001202">CHAPTER XXV. How the Queen of Orkney came to this feast of Pentecost, and Sir Gawaine and his brethren came to ask her blessing.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001211">CHAPTER XXVI. How King Arthur sent for the Lady Lionesse, and how she let cry a tourney at her castle, whereas came many knights.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001222">CHAPTER XXVII. How King Arthur went to the tournament with his knights, and how the lady received him worshipfully, and how the knights encountered.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001231">CHAPTER XXVIII. How the knights bare them in the battle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001242">CHAPTER XXIX. Yet of the said tournament.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001249">CHAPTER XXX. How Sir Gareth was espied by the heralds, and how he escaped out of the field.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001264">CHAPTER XXXI. How Sir Gareth came to a castle where he was well lodged, and he jousted with a knight and slew him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001273">CHAPTER XXXII. How Sir Gareth fought with a knight that held within his castle thirty ladies, and how he slew him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001282">CHAPTER XXXIII. How Sir Gareth and Sir Gawaine fought each against other, and how they knew each other by the damosel Linet.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001303">CHAPTER XXXIV. How Sir Gareth acknowledged that they loved each other to King Arthur, and of the appointment of their wedding.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001316">CHAPTER XXXV. Of the Great Royalty, and what officers were made at the feast of the wedding, and of the jousts at the feast.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001331">BOOK VIII.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001334">CHAPTER I. How Sir Tristram de Liones was born, and how his mother died at his birth, wherefore she named him Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001343">CHAPTER II. How the stepmother of Sir Tristram had ordained poison for to have poisoned Sir Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001354">CHAPTER III. How Sir Tristram was sent into France, and had one to govern him named Gouvernail, and how he learned to harp, hawk, and hunt.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001363">CHAPTER IV. How Sir Marhaus came out of Ireland for to ask truage of Cornwall, or else he would fight therefore.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001372">CHAPTER V. How Tristram enterprized the battle to fight for the truage of Cornwall, and how he was made knight.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001383">CHAPTER VI. How Sir Tristram arrived into the Island for to furnish the battle with Sir Marhaus.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001390">CHAPTER VII. How Sir Tristram fought against Sir Marhaus and achieved his battle, and how Sir Marhaus fled to his ship.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001401">CHAPTER VIII. How Sir Marhaus after that he was arrived in Ireland died of the stroke that Sir Tristram had given him, and how Tristram was hurt.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001412">CHAPTER IX. How Sir Tristram was put to the keeping of La Beale Isoud first for to be healed of his wound.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001423">CHAPTER X. How Sir Tristram won the degree at a tournament in Ireland, and there made Palamides to bear no more harness in a year.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001434">CHAPTER XI. How the queen espied that Sir Tristram had slain her brother Sir Marhaus by his sword, and in what jeopardy he was.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001445">CHAPTER XII. How Sir Tristram departed from the king and La Beale Isoud out of Ireland for to come into Cornwall.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001456">CHAPTER XIII. How Sir Tristram and King Mark hurted each other for the love of a knight's wife.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001467">CHAPTER XIV. How Sir Tristram lay with the lady, and how her husband fought with Sir Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001476">CHAPTER XV. How Sir Bleoberis demanded the fairest lady in King Mark's court, whom he took away, and how he was fought with.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001485">CHAPTER XVI. How Sir Tristram fought with two knights of the Round Table.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001494">CHAPTER XVII. How Sir Tristram fought with Sir Bleoberis for a lady, and how the lady was put to choice to whom she would go.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001501">CHAPTER XVIII. How the lady forsook Sir Tristram and abode with Sir Bleoberis, and how she desired to go to her husband.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001510">CHAPTER XIX. How King Mark sent Sir Tristram for La Beale Isoud toward Ireland, and how by fortune he arrived into England.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001517">CHAPTER XX. How King Anguish of Ireland was summoned to come to King Arthur's court for treason.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001524">CHAPTER XXI. How Sir Tristram rescued a child from a knight, and how Gouvernail told him of King Anguish.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001533">CHAPTER XXII. How Sir Tristram fought for Sir Anguish and overcame his adversary, and how his adversary would never yield him.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001542">CHAPTER XXIII. How Sir Blamore desired Tristram to slay him, and how Sir Tristram spared him, and how they took appointment.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001553">CHAPTER XXIV. How Sir Tristram demanded La Beale Isoud for King Mark, and how Sir Tristram and Isoud drank the love drink.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001562">CHAPTER XXV. How Sir Tristram and Isoud were in prison, and how he fought for her beauty, and smote off another lady's head.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001569">CHAPTER XXVI. How Sir Tristram fought with Sir Breunor, and at the last smote off his head.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001578">CHAPTER XXVII. How Sir Galahad fought with Sir Tristram, and how Sir Tristram yielded him and promised to fellowship with Launcelot.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001587">CHAPTER XXVIII. How Sir Launcelot met with Sir Carados bearing away Sir Gawaine, and of the rescue of Sir Gawaine.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001592">CHAPTER XXIX. Of the wedding of King Mark to La Beale Isoud, and of Bragwaine her maid, and of Palamides.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001597">CHAPTER XXX. How Palamides demanded Queen Isoud, and how Lambegus rode after to rescue her, and of the escape of Isoud.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001606">CHAPTER XXXI. How Sir Tristram rode after Palamides, and how he found him and fought with him, and by the means of Isoud the battle ceased.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001611">CHAPTER XXXII. How Sir Tristram brought Queen Isoud home, and of the debate of King Mark and Sir Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001618">CHAPTER XXXIII. How Sir Lamorak jousted with thirty knights, and Sir Tristram at the request of King Mark smote his horse down.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001625">CHAPTER XXXIV. How Sir Lamorak sent an horn to King Mark in despite of Sir Tristram, and how Sir Tristram was driven into a chapel.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001636">CHAPTER XXXV. How Sir Tristram was holpen by his men, and of Queen Isoud which was put in a lazar-cote, and how Tristram was hurt.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001643">CHAPTER XXXVI. How Sir Tristram served in war King Howel of Brittany, and slew his adversary in the field.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001650">CHAPTER XXXVII. How Sir Suppinabiles told Sir Tristram how he was defamed in the court of King Arthur, and of Sir Lamorak.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001659">CHAPTER XXXVIII. How Sir Tristram and his wife arrived in Wales, and how he met there with Sir Lamorak.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001666">CHAPTER XXXIX. How Sir Tristram fought with Sir Nabon, and overcame him, and made Sir Segwarides lord of the isle.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001675">CHAPTER XL
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001684">CHAPTER XLI. How Sir Lamorak slew Sir Frol, and of the courteous fighting with Sir Belliance his brother.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001695">BOOK IX.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001698">CHAPTER I. How a young man came into the court of King Arthur, and how Sir Kay called him in scorn La Cote Male Taile.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001705">CHAPTER II. How a damosel came into the court and desired a knight to take on him an enquest, which La Cote Male Taile emprised.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001712">CHAPTER III. How La Cote Male Taile overthrew Sir Dagonet the king's fool, and of the rebuke that he had of the damosel.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001719">CHAPTER IV. How La Cote Male Taile fought against an hundred knights, and how he escaped by the mean of a lady.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001730">CHAPTER V. How Sir Launcelot came to the court and heard of La Cote Male Taile, and how he followed after him, and how La Cote Male Taile was prisoner.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001741">CHAPTER VI. How Sir Launcelot fought with six knights, and after with Sir Brian, and how he delivered the prisoners.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001750">CHAPTER VII. How Sir Launcelot met with the damosel named Male disant, and named her the Damosel Bienpensant.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001759">CHAPTER VIII. How La Cote Male Taile was taken prisoner, and after rescued by Sir Launcelot, and how Sir Launcelot overcame four brethren.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001768">CHAPTER IX. How Sir Launcelot made La Cote Male Taile lord of the Castle of Pendragon, and after was made knight of the Round Table.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001773">CHAPTER X. How La Beale Isoud sent letters to Sir Tristram by her maid Bragwaine, and of divers adventures of Sir Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001780">CHAPTER XI. How Sir Tristram met with Sir Lamorak de Galis, and how they fought, and after accorded never to fight together.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001785">CHAPTER XII. How Sir Palomides followed the Questing Beast, and smote down Sir Tristram and Sir Lamorak with one spear.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001792">CHAPTER XIII. How Sir Lamorak met with Sir Meliagaunce, and fought together for the beauty of Dame Guenever.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001803">CHAPTER XIV. How Sir Kay met with Sir Tristram, and after of the shame spoken of the knights of Cornwall, and how they jousted.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001810">CHAPTER XV. How King Arthur was brought into the Forest Perilous, and how Sir Tristram saved his life.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001819">CHAPTER XVI. How Sir Tristram came to La Beale Isoud, and how Kehydius began to love Beale Isoud, and of a letter that Tristram found.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001826">CHAPTER XVII. How Sir Tristram departed from Tintagil, and how he sorrowed and was so long in a forest till he was out of his mind.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001833">CHAPTER XVIII. How Sir Tristram soused Dagonet in a well, and how Palomides sent a damosel to seek Tristram, and how Palomides met with King Mark.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001842">CHAPTER XIX. How it was noised how Sir Tristram was dead, and how La Beale Isoud would have slain herself.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001849">CHAPTER XX. How King Mark found Sir Tristram naked, and made him to be borne home to Tintagil, and how he was there known by a brachet.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001858">CHAPTER XXI. How King Mark, by the advice of his council, banished Sir Tristram out of Cornwall the term of ten years.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001865">CHAPTER XXII. How a damosel sought help to help Sir Launcelot against thirty knights, and how Sir Tristram fought with them.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001874">CHAPTER XXIII. How Sir Tristram and Sir Dinadan came to a lodging where they must joust with two knights.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001883">CHAPTER XXIV. How Sir Tristram jousted with Sir Kay and Sir Sagramore le Desirous, and how Sir Gawaine turned Sir Tristram from Morgan le Fay.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001890">CHAPTER XXV. How Sir Tristram and Sir Gawaine rode to have foughten with the thirty knights, but they durst not come out.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001897">CHAPTER XXVI. How damosel Bragwaine found Tristram sleeping by a well, and how she delivered letters to him from La Beale Isoud.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001904">CHAPTER XXVII. How Sir Tristram had a fall with Sir Palomides, and how Launcelot overthrew two knights.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001913">CHAPTER XXVIII. How Sir Launcelot jousted with Palomides and overthrew him, and after he was assailed with twelve knights.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001920">CHAPTER XXIX. How Sir Tristram behaved him the first day of the tournament, and there he had the prize.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001927">CHAPTER XXX. How Sir Tristram returned against King Arthur's party because he saw Sir Palomides on that party.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001940">CHAPTER XXXI. How Sir Tristram found Palomides by a well, and brought him with him to his lodging.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001949">CHAPTER XXXII. How Sir Tristram smote down Sir Palomides, and how he jousted with King Arthur, and other feats.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001956">CHAPTER XXXIII. How Sir Launcelot hurt Sir Tristram, and how after Sir Tristram smote down Sir Palomides.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001965">CHAPTER XXXIV. How the prize of the third day was given to Sir Launcelot, and Sir Launcelot gave it to Sir Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001972">CHAPTER XXXV. How Palomides came to the castle where Sir Tristram was, and of the quest that Sir Launcelot and ten knights made for Sir Tristram.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001981">CHAPTER XXXVI. How Sir Tristram, Sir Palomides, and Sir Dinadan were taken and put in prison.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001990">CHAPTER XXXVII. How King Mark was sorry for the good renown of Sir Tristram. Some of King Arthur's knights jousted with knights of Cornwall.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000001999">CHAPTER XXXVIII. Of the treason of King Mark, and how Sir Gaheris smote him down and Andred his cousin.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000002008">CHAPTER XXXIX. How after that Sir Tristram, Sir Palomides, and Sir Dinadan had been long in prison they were delivered.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000002019">CHAPTER XL. How Sir Dinadan rescued a lady from Sir Breuse Saunce Pité, and how Sir Tristram received a shield of Morgan le Fay.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000002026">CHAPTER XLI. How Sir Tristram took with him the shield, and also how he slew the paramour of Morgan le Fay.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000002031">CHAPTER XLII. How Morgan le Fay buried her paramour, and how Sir Tristram praised Sir Launcelot and his kin.
<$link class="pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000002038">CHAPTER XLIII. How Sir Tristram at a tournament bare the shield that Morgan le Fay delivered to him.
<$link class="c1 pginternal" to="$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000002047">GLOSSARY
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000009": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000009", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000010": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000010", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

BIBLIOGRAPHICAL NOTE

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000011": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000011", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000012": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000012", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The Morte D’Arthur was finished, as the epilogue tells us, in the ninth year of Edward IV., i.e. between March 4, 1469 and the same date in 1470. It is thus, fitly enough, the last important English book written before the introduction of printing into this country, and since no manuscript of it has come down to us it is also the first English classic for our knowledge of which we are entirely dependent on a printed text. Caxton’s story of how the book was brought to him and he was induced to print it may be read farther on in his own preface. From this we learn also that he was not only the printer of the book, but to some extent its editor also, dividing Malory’s work into twenty-one books, splitting up the books into chapters, by no means skilfully, and supplying the “Rubrish” or chapter-headings. It may be added that Caxton’s preface contains, moreover, a brief criticism which, on the points on which it touches, is still the soundest and most sympathetic that has been written.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000013": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000013", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000014": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000014", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Caxton finished his edition the last day of July 1485, some fifteen or sixteen years after Malory wrote his epilogue. It is clear that the author was then dead, or the printer would not have acted as a clumsy editor to the book, and recent discoveries (if bibliography may, for the moment, enlarge its bounds to mention such matters) have revealed with tolerable certainty when Malory died and who he was. In letters to The Athenaeum in July 1896 Mr. T. Williams pointed out that the name of a Sir Thomas Malorie occurred among those of a number of other Lancastrians excluded from a general pardon granted by Edward IV. in 1468, and that a William Mallerye was mentioned in the same year as taking part in a Lancastrian rising. In September 1897, again, in another letter to the same paper, Mr. A. T. Martin reported the finding of the will of a Thomas Malory of Papworth, a hundred partly in Cambridgeshire, partly in Hunts. This will was made on September 16, 1469, and as it was proved the 27th of the next month the testator must have been in immediate expectation of death. It contains the most careful provision for the education and starting in life of a family of three daughters and seven sons, of whom the youngest seems to have been still an infant. We cannot say with certainty that this Thomas Malory, whose last thoughts were so busy for his children, was our author, or that the Lancastrian knight discovered by Mr. Williams was identical with either or both, but such evidence as the Morte D’Arthur offers favours such a belief. There is not only the epilogue with its petition, “pray for me while I am alive that God send me good deliverance and when I am dead pray you all for my soul,” but this very request is foreshadowed at the end of chap. 37 of Book ix. in the touching passage, surely inspired by personal experience, as to the sickness “that is the greatest pain a prisoner may have”; and the reflections on English fickleness in the first chapter of Book xxi., though the Wars of the Roses might have inspired them in any one, come most naturally from an author who was a Lancastrian knight.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000015": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000015", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000016": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000016", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

If the Morte D’Arthur was really written in prison and by a prisoner distressed by ill-health as well as by lack of liberty, surely no task was ever better devised to while away weary hours. Leaving abundant scope for originality in selection, modification, and arrangement, as a compilation and translation it had in it that mechanical element which adds the touch of restfulness to literary work. No original, it is said, has yet been found for Book vii., and it is possible that none will ever be forthcoming for chap. 20 of Book xviii., which describes the arrival of the body of the Fair Maiden of Astolat at Arthur’s court, or vii for chap. 25 of the same book, with its discourse on true love; but the great bulk of the work has been traced chapter by chapter to the “Merlin” of Robert de Borron and his successors (Bks. i.-iv.), the English metrical romance La Morte Arthur of the Thornton manuscript (Bk. v.), the French romances of Tristan (Bks. viii.-x.) and of Launcelot (Bks. vi., xi.-xix.), and lastly to the English prose Morte Arthur of Harley MS. 2252 (Bks. xviii., xx., xxi.). As to Malory’s choice of his authorities critics have not failed to point out that now and again he gives a worse version where a better has come down to us, and if he had been able to order a complete set of Arthurian manuscripts from his bookseller, no doubt he would have done even better than he did! But of the skill, approaching to original genius, with which he used the books from which he worked there is little dispute.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000017": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000017", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000018": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000018", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Malory died leaving his work obviously unrevised, and in this condition it was brought to Caxton, who prepared it for the press with his usual enthusiasm in the cause of good literature, and also, it must be added, with his usual carelessness. New chapters are sometimes made to begin in the middle of a sentence, and in addition to simple misprints there are numerous passages in which it is impossible to believe that we have the text as Malory intended it to stand. After Caxton’s edition Malory’s manuscript must have disappeared, and subsequent editions are differentiated only by the degree of closeness with which they follow the first. Editions appeared printed by Wynkyn de Worde in 1498 and 1529, by William Copland in 1559, by Thomas East about 1585, and by Thomas Stansby in 1634, each printer apparently taking the text of his immediate predecessor and reproducing it with modifications. Stansby’s edition served for reprints in 1816 and 1856 (the latter edited by Thomas Wright); but in 1817 an edition supervised by Robert Southey went back to Caxton’s text, though to a copy (only two are extant, and only one perfect!) in which eleven leaves were supplied from Wynkyn de Worde’s reprint. In 1868 Sir Edward Strachey produced for the present publishers a reprint of Southey’s text in modern spelling, with the substitution of current words for those now obsolete, and the softening of a handful of passages likely, he thought, to prevent the book being placed in the hands of boys. In 1889 a boon was conferred on scholars by the publication of Dr. H. Oskar Sommer’s page-for-page reprint of Caxton’s text, with an elaborate discussion of Malory’s sources. Dr. Sommer’s edition was used by Sir E. Strachey to revise his Globe text, and in 1897 Mr. Israel Gollancz produced for the “Temple Classics” a very pretty edition in which Sir Edward Strachey’s principles of modernisation in spelling and punctuation were adopted, but with the restoration of obsolete words and omitted phrases. As to the present edition, Sir Edward Strachey altered with so sparing a hand that on many pages differences between his version and that here printed will be looked for in vain; but the most anxious care has been taken to produce a text modernised as to its spelling, but in other respects in accurate accordance with Caxton’s text, as represented by Dr Sommer’s reprint. Obvious misprints have been silently corrected, but in a few cases notes show where emendations have been introduced from Wynkyn de Worde—not that Wynkyn had any more right to emend Caxton than we, but because even a printer’s conjecture gains a little sanctity after four centuries. The restoration of obsolete words has necessitated a much fuller glossary, and the index of names has therefore been separated from it and enlarged. In its present form the index is the work of Mr. Henry Littlehales.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000019": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000019", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000020": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000020", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

A. W. POLLARD.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000021": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000021", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000022": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000022", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000023": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000023", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

PREFACE OF WILLIAM CAXTON

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000024": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000024", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000025": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000025", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

After that I had accomplished and finished divers histories, as well of contemplation as of other historial and worldly acts of great conquerors and princes, and also certain books of ensamples and doctrine, many noble and divers gentlemen of this realm of England came and demanded me many and oft times, wherefore that I have not do made and imprint the noble history of the Saint Greal, and of the most renowned Christian king, first and chief of the three best Christian, and worthy, King Arthur, which ought most to be remembered among us Englishmen to-fore all other Christian kings; for it is notoyrly known through the universal world, that there be nine worthy and the best that ever were, that is to wit, three Paynims, three Jews, and three Christian men. As for the Paynims, they were to-fore the Incarnation of Christ, which were named, the first Hector of Troy, of whom the history is comen both in ballad and in prose, the second Alexander the Great, and the third Julius Caesar, Emperor of Rome, of whom the histories be well known and had. And as for the three Jews, which also were to-fore the incarnation of our Lord, of whom the first was duke Joshua which brought the children of Israel into the land of behest, the second David king of Jerusalem, and the third Judas Machabeus, of these three the Bible rehearseth all their noble histories and acts. And since the said Incarnation have been three noble Christian men, stalled and admitted through the universal world into the number of the nine best and worthy. Of whom was first the noble Arthur, whose noble acts I purpose to write in this present book here following. The second was Charlemain, or Charles the Great, of whom the history is had in many places, both in French and in English. And the third and last was Godfrey of Boloine, of whose acts and life I made a book unto the excellent prince and king of noble memory, King Edward the Fourth.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000026": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000026", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000027": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000027", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The said noble gentlemen instantly required me to imprint the history of the said noble king and conqueror King Arthur, and of his knights, with the history of the Saint Greal, and of the death and ending of the said Arthur; affirming that I ought rather to imprint his acts and noble feats, than of Godfrey of Boloine, or any of the other eight, considering that he was a man born within this realm, and king and emperor of the same: and that there be in French divers and many noble volumes of his acts, and also of his knights. To whom I answered that divers men hold opinion that there was no such Arthur, and that all such books as been made of him be feigned and fables, because that some chronicles make of him no mention, nor remember him nothing, nor of his knights. Whereto they answered, and one in special said, that in him that should say or think that there was never such a king called Arthur might well be aretted great folly and blindness. For he said that there were many evidences of the contrary. First ye may see his sepulchre in the monastery of Glastonbury. And also in Policronicon, in the fifth book the sixth chapter, and in the seventh book the twenty-third chapter, where his body was buried, and after found, and translated into the said monastery. Ye shall see also in the history of Bochas, in his book De Casu Principum, part of his noble acts, and also of his fall. Also Galfridus in his British book recounteth his life: and in divers places of England many remembrances be yet of him, and shall remain perpetually, and also of his knights. First in the abbey of Westminster, at St. Edward’s shrine, remaineth the print of his seal in red wax closed in beryl, in which is written, Patricius Arthurus Britannie, Gallie, Germanie, Dacie, Imperator. Item in the castle of Dover ye may see Gawaine’s skull, and Cradok’s mantle: at Winchester the Round Table: in other places Launcelot’s sword and many other things. Then all these things considered, there can no man reasonably gainsay but there was a king of this land named Arthur. For in all places, Christian and heathen, he is reputed and taken for one of the nine worthy, and the first of the three Christian men. And also, he is more spoken of beyond the sea, more books made of his noble acts, than there be in England, as well in Dutch, Italian, Spanish, and Greekish, as in French. And yet of record remain in witness of him in Wales, in the town of Camelot, the great stones and the marvellous works of iron lying under the ground, and royal vaults, which divers now living have seen. Wherefore it is a marvel why he is no more renowned in his own country, save only it accordeth to the Word of God, which saith that no man is accepted for a prophet in his own country.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000028": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000028", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000029": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000029", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Then all these things aforesaid alleged, I could not well deny but that there was such a noble king named Arthur, and reputed one of the nine worthy, and first and chief of the Christian men. And many noble volumes be made of him and of his noble knights in French, which I have seen and read beyond the sea, which be not had in our maternal tongue. But in Welsh be many and also in French, and some in English but nowhere nigh all. Wherefore, such as have late been drawn out briefly into English I have after the simple conning that God hath sent to me, under the favour and correction of all noble lords and gentlemen, enprised to imprint a book of the noble histories of the said King Arthur, and of certain of his knights, after a copy unto me delivered, which copy Sir Thomas Malorye did take out of certain books of French, and reduced it into English. And I, according to my copy, have done set it in imprint, to the intent that noble men may see and learn the noble acts of chivalry, the gentle and virtuous deeds that some knights used in those days, by which they came to honour, and how they that were vicious were punished and oft put to shame and rebuke; humbly beseeching all noble lords and ladies, with all other estates of what estate or degree they been of, that shall see and read in this said book and work, that they take the good and honest acts in their remembrance, and to follow the same. Wherein they shall find many joyous and pleasant histories, and noble and renowned acts of humanity, gentleness, and chivalry. For herein may be seen noble chivalry, courtesy, humanity, friendliness, hardiness, love, friendship, cowardice, murder, hate, virtue, and sin. Do after the good and leave the evil, and it shall bring you to good fame and renown. And for to pass the time this book shall be pleasant to read in, but for to give faith and belief that all is true that is contained herein, ye be at your liberty: but all is written for our doctrine, and for to beware that we fall not to vice nor sin, but to exercise and follow virtue, by which we may come and attain to good fame and renown in this life, and after this short and transitory life to come unto everlasting bliss in heaven; the which He grant us that reigneth in heaven, the blessed Trinity. Amen.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000030": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000030", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000031": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000031", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Then to proceed forth in this said book, which I direct unto all noble princes, lords and ladies, gentlemen or gentlewomen, that desire to read or hear read of the noble and joyous history of the great conqueror and excellent king, King Arthur, sometime king of this noble realm, then called Britain; I, William Caxton, simple person, present this book following, which I have enprised to imprint: and treateth of the noble acts, feats of arms of chivalry, prowess, hardiness, humanity, love, courtesy, and very gentleness, with many wonderful histories and adventures. And for to understand briefly the content of this volume, I have divided it into XXI Books, and every book chaptered, as hereafter shall by God’s grace follow. The First Book shall treat how Uther Pendragon gat the noble conqueror King Arthur, and containeth xxviii chapters. The Second Book treateth of Balin the noble knight, and containeth xix chapters. The Third Book treateth of the marriage of King Arthur to Queen Guenever, with other matters, and containeth xv chapters. The Fourth Book, how Merlin was assotted, and of war made to King Arthur, and containeth xxix chapters. The Fifth Book treateth of the conquest of Lucius the emperor, and containeth xii chapters. The Sixth Book treateth of Sir Launcelot and Sir Lionel, and marvellous adventures, and containeth xviii chapters. The Seventh Book treateth of a noble knight called Sir Gareth, and named by Sir Kay Beaumains, and containeth xxxvi chapters. The Eighth Book treateth of the birth of Sir Tristram the noble knight, and of his acts, and containeth xli chapters. The Ninth Book treateth of a knight named by Sir Kay Le Cote Male Taille, and also of Sir Tristram, and containeth xliv chapters. The Tenth Book treateth of Sir Tristram, and other marvellous adventures, and containeth lxxxviii chapters. The Eleventh Book treateth of Sir Launcelot and Sir Galahad, and containeth xiv chapters. The Twelfth Book treateth of Sir Launcelot and his madness, and containeth xiv chapters. The Thirteenth Book treateth how Galahad came first to king Arthur’s court, and the quest how the Sangreal was begun, and containeth xx chapters. The Fourteenth Book treateth of the quest of the Sangreal, and containeth x chapters. The Fifteenth Book treateth of Sir Launcelot, and containeth vi chapters. The Sixteenth Book treateth of Sir Bors and Sir Lionel his brother, and containeth xvii chapters. The Seventeenth Book treateth of the Sangreal, and containeth xxiii chapters. The Eighteenth Book treateth of Sir Launcelot and the queen, and containeth xxv chapters. The Nineteenth Book treateth of Queen Guenever and Launcelot, and containeth xiii chapters. The Twentieth Book treateth of the piteous death of Arthur, and containeth xxii chapters. The Twenty-first Book treateth of his last departing, and how Sir Launcelot came to revenge his death, and containeth xiii chapters. The sum is twenty-one books, which contain the sum of five hundred and seven chapters, as more plainly shall follow hereafter.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000032": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000032", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000033": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000033", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000034": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000034", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

BOOK I.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000035": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000035", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000036": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000036", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000037": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000037", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

CHAPTER I.
First, How Uther Pendragon sent for the duke of Cornwall and Igraine his wife, and of their departing suddenly again.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000038": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000038", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000039": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000039", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

It befell in the days of Uther Pendragon, when he was king of all England, and so reigned, that there was a mighty duke in Cornwall that held war against him long time. And the duke was called the Duke of Tintagil. And so by means King Uther sent for this duke, charging him to bring his wife with him, for she was called a fair lady, and a passing wise, and her name was called Igraine.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000040": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000040", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000041": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000041", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

So when the duke and his wife were come unto the king, by the means of great lords they were accorded both. The king liked and loved this lady well, and he made them great cheer out of measure, and desired to have lain by her. But she was a passing good woman, and would not assent unto the king. And then she told the duke her husband, and said, I suppose that we were sent for that I should be dishonoured; wherefore, husband, I counsel you, that we depart from hence suddenly, that we may ride all night unto our own castle. And in like wise as she said so they departed, that neither the king nor none of his council were ware of their departing. All so soon as King Uther knew of their departing so suddenly, he was wonderly wroth. Then he called to him his privy council, and told them of the sudden departing of the duke and his wife.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000042": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000042", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000043": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000043", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Then they advised the king to send for the duke and his wife by a great charge; and if he will not come at your summons, then may ye do your best, then have ye cause to make mighty war upon him. So that was done, and the messengers had their answers; and that was this shortly, that neither he nor his wife would not come at him.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000044": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000044", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000045": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000045", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Then was the king wonderly wroth. And then the king sent him plain word again, and bade him be ready and stuff him and garnish him, for within forty days he would fetch him out of the biggest castle that he hath.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000046": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000046", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000047": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000047", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

When the duke had this warning, anon he went and furnished and garnished two strong castles of his, of the which the one hight Tintagil, and the other castle hight Terrabil. So his wife Dame Igraine he put in the castle of Tintagil, and himself he put in the castle of Terrabil, the which had many issues and posterns out. Then in all haste came Uther with a great host, and laid a siege about the castle of Terrabil. And there he pight many pavilions, and there was great war made on both parties, and much people slain. Then for pure anger and for great love of fair Igraine the king Uther fell sick. So came to the king Uther Sir Ulfius, a noble knight, and asked the king why he was sick. I shall tell thee, said the king, I am sick for anger and for love of fair Igraine, that I may not be whole. Well, my lord, said Sir Ulfius, I shall seek Merlin, and he shall do you remedy, that your heart shall be pleased. So Ulfius departed, and by adventure he met Merlin in a beggar’s array, and there Merlin asked Ulfius whom he sought. And he said he had little ado to tell him. Well, said Merlin, I know whom thou seekest, for thou seekest Merlin; therefore seek no farther, for I am he; and if King Uther will well reward me, and be sworn unto me to fulfil my desire, that shall be his honour and profit more than mine; for I shall cause him to have all his desire. All this will I undertake, said Ulfius, that there shall be nothing reasonable but thou shalt have thy desire. Well, said Merlin, he shall have his intent and desire. And therefore, said Merlin, ride on your way, for I will not be long behind.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000048": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000048", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000049": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000049", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000050": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000050", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

CHAPTER II.
How Uther Pendragon made war on the duke of Cornwall, and how by the mean of Merlin he lay by the duchess and gat Arthur.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000051": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000051", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000052": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000052", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Then Ulfius was glad, and rode on more than a pace till that he came to King Uther Pendragon, and told him he had met with Merlin. Where is he? said the king. Sir, said Ulfius, he will not dwell long. Therewithal Ulfius was ware where Merlin stood at the porch of the pavilion’s door. And then Merlin was bound to come to the king. When King Uther saw him, he said he was welcome. Sir, said Merlin, I know all your heart every deal; so ye will be sworn unto me as ye be a true king anointed, to fulfil my desire, ye shall have your desire. Then the king was sworn upon the Four Evangelists. Sir, said Merlin, this is my desire: the first night that ye shall lie by Igraine ye shall get a child on her, and when that is born, that it shall be delivered to me for to nourish there as I will have it; for it shall be your worship, and the child’s avail, as mickle as the child is worth. I will well, said the king, as thou wilt have it. Now make you ready, said Merlin, this night ye shall lie with Igraine in the castle of Tintagil; and ye shall be like the duke her husband, Ulfius shall be like Sir Brastias, a knight of the duke’s, and I will be like a knight that hight Sir Jordanus, a knight of the duke’s. But wait ye make not many questions with her nor her men, but say ye are diseased, and so hie you to bed, and rise not on the morn till I come to you, for the castle of Tintagil is but ten miles hence; so this was done as they devised. But the duke of Tintagil espied how the king rode from the siege of Terrabil, and therefore that night he issued out of the castle at a postern for to have distressed the king’s host. And so, through his own issue, the duke himself was slain or ever the king came at the castle of Tintagil.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000053": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000053", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000054": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/22bf6e83cee936d3/text/000000054", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

So after the death of the duke, King Uther lay with Igraine more than three hours after his death, and begat on her that night Arthur, and on day came Merlin to the king, and bade him make him ready, and so he kissed the lady Igraine and departed in all haste. But when the lady heard tell of the duke her husband, and by all record he was dead or ever King Uther came to her, then she marvelled who that might be that lay with her in likeness of her lord; so she mourned privily and held her peace. Then all the barons by one assent prayed the king of accord betwixt the lady Igraine and him; the king gave them leave, for fain would he have been accorded with her.
